content.webTitle: Twin Peaks fans party on as show plots return to weird heart of America

fields.headline: Twin Peaks fans party on as show plots return to weird heart of America
fields.bodyText: They have kept the flame alive for 21 years and, last week, the organisers of the annual Twin Peaks Fest attended by loyal fans since 1993 got their reward. The announcement that cult TV series Twin Peaks will be revived as a nine-episode series in 2016 has seen sales of $300 tickets skyrocket as fans revel in the prospect of renewing acquaintance with FBI special agent Dale Cooper and his fondness for cherry pie and coffee. Tickets for the event – held every July in North Bend, Washington, where Twin Peaks was partly filmed – went on sale on 1 October, and last week’s news has ensured that next summer’s event will attract record numbers. “We’re delighted,” festival organiser Rob Lindley told the Observer. “We’d never given up hope the series would come back.” He said the gathering, which typically draws around 200, makes up in perversity – including cherry stem-tying contests and a plastic-wrapped party – what it lacks in numbers. The storyline of the original series, which is set in a typical Pacific north-west lumber town, nominally sought to solve the murder of the town’s homecoming queen, who is discovered wrapped in plastic by the river. With a backwards-talking dwarf – the Man from Another Place – and other oddities, the series was a natural successor to Lynch’s film Blue Velvet and forerunner to The X-Files. Series co-creator, Mark Frost, explained last week that he and Lynch had felt “a sense of responsibility” to fans who’d never given up hope. “It never insulted the viewer’s intelligence – it always made you think,” said Lindley. The original series, with its strange non-linear narrative of small-town America obscuring an underbelly of Satanic abuse, provided a memorable Sunday-night vehicle for philosophical rumination. Lindley said the show’s enduring appeal might hinge on its refusal to answer its own underlying mysteries. “[Lynch] had us wondering about things above the stars and below the earth. He talked about UFOs, the Black Lodge, the White Lodge, the spirits, owls, the humans and their emotions. He grabbed people from different angles.” Anticipation that Lynch and Frost were planning a revival had been building, said Pieter Dom, founder of the Welcome to Twin Peaks fansite. He’d heard rumours of the new series, but they’d always been shot down. The return of Twin Peaks raises the question of whether it can recapture the weirdness of the original. “I’m not worried,” Dom said. “There must be a good reason or they wouldn’t do it. They’re going to blow our minds.” Frost and Lynch face a quandary: answer the story’s many questions and the series could lose its mystery; yet without mystery, there is no Twin Peaks. Critics warn that fans who think they want answers, really don’t. Frost told the Los Angeles Times that Cooper’s fate was “not going to be something that will seem ambiguous when you see it”. Asked why the series continued to be so popular when there are so many dark, experimental stories on TV, he couldn’t say. “People seem to remember it even better than we do. It’s kind of an important thing for a lot of people.” However, Hollywood blogger Jeffrey Wells claimed that the original Twin Peaks was out of ideas by the time it was cancelled. To revive it, he said, “Lynch is basically admitting he’s run out of ideas.” One character unlikely to reappear is the terrifying, denim-clad killer Bob, played by set director Frank Silva. Frost said that despite “haunting the dreams of millions of Americans” Silva, who died in 1995, was “the nicest man you’ll ever meet”. It’s that kind of counterpoint that made Twin Peaks so compelling, said Lindley. “Lynch was getting into what we perceive on the outside compared to the evil within. Small-town America and everything’s perfect. But underneath there’s another story; the prom queen is a whore and a cocaine addict. Twin Peaks let that be known.”
